bestBHT.bht: The disciples tried to prevent the people from bringing their infants and young children to Jesus, but He rebuked them. Jesus wanted to bless the little ones and even laid His hands on them and prayed for them. This act followed the venerable custom of invoking a blessing upon children. The disciples' interference was against the mind of Christ, as He desired to show His love and welcome to people of all ages, including the vulnerable and innocent infants.

Henry Alford: The word used by St. Luke points out more distinctly the tender age of the children than that in Matthew and Mark.
Not the people came only, but also brought their children.
The article may be merely generic, as in A.V.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: infants—showing that some, at least, of those called in Matthew and Mark simply 'little' or 'young children,' were literally 'babes.'
put His hands on them and pray," or invoke a 'blessing' on them (Matthew 19:13- :), according to venerable custom (Genesis 48:14; Genesis 48:15).
Repeatedly the disciples thus interposed to save annoyance and interruption to their Master; but, as the result showed, always against the mind of Christ.
Marvin Vincent: Touch. So Mark. Matthew has lay his hands on them and pray.
Archibald T. Robertson: They were bringing their babes, their infants.
Here Mark and Matthew have 'little children' instead of 'babes.'
Either began to rebuke, or continued, kept on rebuking.
John Gill: As well as grown persons, that were sick, to be healed by him.
One of the ways by which Christ healed persons, was by touching them.
But when [his] disciples saw [it], they rebuked them.

bhtAttempts.bht: The word used by Luke in this verse emphasizes the tender age of the children, indicating that they were literal infants. The people not only came themselves but also brought their young children. The disciples, however, tried to keep the children away from Jesus, perhaps thinking they would be an annoyance. Yet, Jesus rebuked his disciples and made it clear that he welcomed the children. He lovingly touched them and prayed for them, following the custom of invoking a blessing on them. The disciples' interference was always against Jesus' desires, as he desired to extend his blessings to all, including the little ones.

The word used by Luke emphasizes the tender age of the children, showing that some were literal infants. The people brought their young children and infants to Jesus, seeking his blessings upon them. The disciples, however, tried to rebuke those who brought their children, in an attempt to shield Jesus from annoyance. But Jesus, in his loving and inclusive nature, rebuked his disciples and welcomed the children with open arms, touching them and praying for them.

The word used by St. Luke points out the tender age of the children, indicating that they were literal babes. The disciples interposed to save annoyance and interruption to their Master but always against the mind of Christ. However, Jesus rebuked his disciples and made it clear that he welcomed the children. He lovingly touched them and prayed for them, following the custom of invoking a blessing on them. The disciples' interference was against Jesus' desires, as he desired to extend his blessings to all, including the little ones.

The word used by St. Luke specifies the tender age of the children, indicating they were literal babes. Jesus' disciples interposed to spare annoyance and interruption to their Master, contrary to His intentions. Yet Jesus rebuked his disciples and made it clear that He welcomed the children. He lovingly touched them and prayed for them, according to the tradition of invoking a blessing upon them. The disciples' interference went against Jesus' desires, for He desired to extend His blessings to all, even the little ones.

The disciples tried to prevent the people from bringing their infants and young children to Jesus, but He rebuked them. Jesus wanted to bless the little ones and even laid His hands on them and prayed for them. This act followed the venerable custom of invoking a blessing upon children. The disciples' interference was against the mind of Christ, as He desired to show His love and welcome to people of all ages, including the vulnerable and innocent infants.
